div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,638] ALEXANDRIA, MONDAY, DECEMBER 17, 1906. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.
Throw Steel Nibs Away!
They waste time, are costly to use, wear out, scratch, etc.
Try a "Swan" Fountain Pen.
Prices from 10/6
Sold by all Stationers and Importers in Cairo and Alexandria.
Catalogue free.
Mable, Todd & Bard, High Holborn, London.

div.head: Orient-Royal Mail Line.
div.p: OUTWARD to AUSTRALIA.
R.M.S. “Ormus" will leave Suez about December 14
R.M.S "Oruba" will leave Suez about December 1.
HOMEWARD to NAPLES, MARSEILLES, GIBRALTAR, PLYMOUTH, LONDON, TILBURY.
R.M.S. "Orotava" will leave Port Said December 27
R.M.S. “Ophir" will leave Port Said December 31

The issue of return tickets to and from Egypt has been discontinued. Passengers paying full fare one direction will, however, be allowed abatement of one-third off fare back if return voyage be made within four months of arrival, or abatement of 20 o/o if return voyage be made within six months of arrival.
Special reduced rates during Summer season 15th May - 15th September.
Agents, Cairo: Thomas Cook & Son, Ltd. ; Alexandria : R. J. Moss & Co.

div.head: Deutsche Levante-Linie.
div.p: Mail and Passenger Steamships. Regular three-weekly Service from HAMBURG, via ANTWERP & MALTA, to ALEXANDRIA and vice-versa, admitting goods from all chief German Railway Stations on direct Bill of Landing to ALEXANDRIA and all chief ports of Egypt, Syria, etc., at favourable through rates of DEUTSCHE VERKEHR (traffic).
EXPECTED AT ALEXANDRIA.
S.S. NAXOS December 13 from Hamburg bound for Hamburg.
S.S. ANDROS December 19 from Anvers.
For tariff and particulars apply to ADOLPHE STROSS, Alexandria, Agent.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: The Moss S.S. Company, Ltd.

*Second class accommodation only, unless specially reserved.—Fares : Alexandria to Liverpool, 1st, £14 Single, £25 Return. 2nd, £9 Single, £15 Return.—To Malta, 1st, £5 Single, £9 Return, 2nd, £3 Single, £5 Return.—Return tickets available for six months.
S.S. Menepthah now on the berth, will sail on or about Tuesday, December 18th, to be followed by S.S. Philaes.

div.head: Austrian Lloyd’s Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Venice-Trieste.

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi, Tuesday a.m. in time for express to Paris, London, Naples, Rome. Arrival Trieste Wednesday noon connecting with Vienna Express (Trieste-Ostende through carriage) and expresses to Italy and Germany.
Fortnightly Service: Alexandria-Brindisi-Venice-Trieste

makes the use of your toothbrush so much more complete and satisfactory, because it perfects the cleansing, and also supplies the necessary antiseptic properties.

div.head: EASTERN EXCHANGE HOTEL, PORT SAID.
div.p: First Class Hotel. Modern in all respects.
Fire-proof, Drained to the Sea, Lifts, Electric Light, English and French Billiards, Fresh and Salt Water Baths.
The Coolest Summer Residence in Egypt.
Special terms to Cairo Residents and their families desirous of enjoying the cool air and sea bathing during the summer months.
Dragomans in Hotel Uniform Meet all Trains and Steamers.

div.head: Tewfik Palace Hotel.
div.p: Helouan, near Cairo.

Formerly the favourite Residence of H.H. the Khedive. Perfect Sanitation.–Purest Desert air. Electric Light. Hot and old baths attached to most rooms. House warmed by special system of Radiators, adjoining the Golf Links and Race Course, Tennis, Billiards, Garden and open air palm house, good stabling , dark room. Excellent Table. Moderate Charges.
Medical Resident Director: Arthur J.M. Bentley, M.D. –Town Office at Stephenson & Co., Opera Square, Cairo.
26 56-31-3-908 P.E HERGEL, MANAGER

div.head: DAILY WEATHER REPORT
div.p: OBSERVATIONS BY THE SURVEY DEPARTMENT.

div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: Fine bracing weather has prevailed and still prevails. The morning opens bright, clear, and chilly with a fresh southerly breeze. Since midnight the glass has been falling, denoting an early change.

ADVERTISEMENTS.—P.T. 4 per line. Minimum charge P.T. 20. Births, Marriages, or Deaths, not exceeding three lines, P.T. 20. Every additional line P.T. 10. Notices in news column P.T. 20 per line. Contracts entered into for standing advertisements.

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette
div.p: An English Daily Newspaper, Established in 1880.
Editor & Manager: R. Snelling.
Price: One Piastre Tariff.
THURSDAY, MONDAY DECEMBER 17, 1906.

div.head: CHILD LABOUR IN EGYPT
div.p: “Al Moayad" remarks that the employment of young girls at the cotton-spinning mills at Mansourah requires the attention of the authorities, and expresses the hope that the Government will, at least, sound the Powers in the hope that it will be possible to arrive at some arrangement enabling a check to be put on the employment in factories, etc., of young children. The Capitulations, of course, stand in the way. We realise the immense difficulties that arise from their existence, and can only be accentuated by their continuance. In the note drawn up by Mr. Brunyate, and appended to Lord Cromer’s report two years ago, this very subject was discussed, and there is no reason to suppose that the rapid commercial development of Egypt is destined to be unattended by attempts at what the Socialist describes as the “exploitation” of the worker. There is nothing to prevent the employment of children under unhealthy or demoralising conditions by foreign capitalists, and we fear that tho national tendency to exaggerate the importance of more money-making may prevent parents from withdrawing their offspring from unhealthy but lucrative employment.

At the same time we agree with “Al Moayad” that steps should be taken to discover to what extent child labour is employed in factories, etc., and, we may add, whether tho facts justify the statements of “A1 Moayad” and the questions asked in the House of Commons. As far as we are aware, little or nothing is known of tho conditions under which tho labouring classes of the country, other than the fellaheen, live and work. The fellah’s way of life and employment are well known, but we imagine that little.has been recorded concerning tho town-workers. Before any legislation can be dreamt of tho Government must have tho facts relative to labour in the towns, so to speak, at its fingers’ ends. The creation of the Statistical Bureau has given Egypt a department to which the exploration of a difficult but highly important subject might well be committed.

div.head: Local and General
div.p: Cattle Plague
Cattle plague has broken out in the province of Minieh.
Prisons
The chief town of a moudirieh will hence- forth be provided with a central prison.
Quarantine.
Quarantine restrictions as against plague have been applied in Egyptian ports to arrivals from Moulmein.
New Court for Delingat
A Summary Court is to be established in the new Delingat Marker, Behera Moudirieh, at the beginning of the year.
Native Penal Code
A handy translation of the Penal Code of the Native Tribunals has been published by Diemer, Cairo. The price is P.T. 15.
Accession DayFetes.
The second list of subscribers to the lands for the celebration of the Khedive's accession anniversary brings the total op to L B. 579.
The Pilgrimage.
The Ministry of the Interior has issued a notice warning pilgrims who wish to accompany the Mahmal to Mecca to be at 8nex by January 3 at latest.
Army Lecture.

The fifth Army lecture of the winter season will be delivered by Major Hardy, R.A.M.C., en “Water supplies and water purification,” at 6 p m. on Tuesday evening, in the Model Room at Headquarters, Cairo.
German Training Chip.

The German training ship Charlotte arrived at Alexandria yesterday from Smyrna, and exchanged salutes with Port Saleh and H.M.S. Venus. This morning, the German Vice-Consul paid an official visit to the commandant.
Public Health Dept.

MM. Samson Rabinovitch, Tewfik Noury, Epaminondas D. Harissi, Ahmed Abd el-Salam, and Mohamed Abd-el Magnid, physicians, and Wilhelm Gehlsen and Yanco Nicopides, pharmacists, have been authorized to practice in Egypt.
A Generous Loan.

M. George Zervodachi has announced that he will grant a loan of £60.000 to the Greek Orthodox Patriarchate at Jerusalem for the treasury of the Holy Sepulchre in order to cover the debt of that institution. He is only asking 2 percent.
Fatal Accident

On Saturday afternoon a native porter attempted to pass between the buffers of two wagons at Gabbary station with a sack of coal on his back. He was, however, run over, and received serious injuries, to which he succumbed shortly afterwards on the way to hospital.
Creek Fleet Lottery.

The following eleven numbers were announced at the fourth drawing at Athens on the 15th isnt. of the National Hellenic Fleet Lottery: 347,536; 864.453; 833,346; 519,013; 204 164; 831,382; 743,251; 400.853; 433,254; 734 290;598,155. Farther particulars can be obtained from Mr. Daniel Fokas, Alexandria.
Egypt and Levant Steamship Company Limited.

We are informed that the accounts of the Egypt and Levant Steamship Company Limited will be made up to 31st December 1906 instead of the 1st May 1907, thus making the first period of the company one of 8 months. We understand this is done so that the annual meetings of the company may be always held in the spring of the year.
An Interesting Conference.

The celebrated aeronaut Spelterini will give a conference, illustrated by a series of views taken from a balloon at from 5,000 to 6,000 metres altitude, tomorrow night, at 9:30, in the Salle des Fetes of the New Khedivial Hotel. In view of the fame of this intrepid aeronaut, who is so well known on the Continent, a large number of spectators may be expected.
New Theatre Tour Eiffel.

This theatre still maintains its position a; a favourite haunt for those seeking amusement, and is nightly crowded. The programme, which is of the usual music hall type, is an excellent one and contains several new names; notable among these are the Eight Otlesslys, who go through several evolutions and dances and secure a deal of applause. Miss Lizzie d’Avery, a Mexican Creole, also comes in for a good share of appreciation for her coon songs and dances. Mile. Bijon in an old favourite at this house, and the other artistes all acquit themselves well and help towards the success of the best shows of the kind in town at present.

div.p: The Exhibition at Messrs. Walker and Meimarachi's Stores merits inspection.
Customers will find there a large assortment of goods of every description suitable for Christmas and New Year presents. 29108-1

div.head: GOVERNMENT POSTAGE.
div.p: NEW REGULATIONS.

Hitherto all the Ministries and Government Departments have been accustomed to send all their letters, parcels, eta, through the Egyptian Post Office free of charge. This system is to come to an end on February 1, 1907, when this class of postal matter, so far as letters are concerned, will be pot in the same position as ordinary public correspondence.

The "Service de l’Etat" stamp, which was affixed regardless of weight, will be superseded by the ordinary stamps with an overprint showing that the correspondence emanates from the Government. The letters will be charged according to weight. Parcels will be treated on the same footing as ordinary parcels, and the usual stamps will be employed with- out an overprint in the case of money-orders commissions will be paid on the spot instead of allowing accounts to run as heretofore.
This new system is to be introduced for the purpose of protecting the Postal Administration and should materially increase its receipts.
TESTIMONIAL TO DEAN BUTCHER.
Lord Cromer's Appeal.
The Earl of Cromer has sent to the "Times" the following appeal for the fond being raised to present a testimonial to Dean Butcher:

Sir, —At a meeting held at the British Agency on November 28 it was decided to invite subscriptions with a view to present a testimonial to the Very Rev. Dean Butcher, who is about to leave Egypt after having held the post of chaplain of All Saints' Church, Cairo, for a period of 26 years.
I shall feel greatly obliged if you will allow me, through your columns, to bring the matter to the notice of the numerous friends of Dean Butcher who are no longer resident in Egypt.
Subscriptions may be sent to the manager of the National Bank of Egypt, Cairo.
I am, Sir, very faithfully yours,
CROMER.
Cairo,Nov. 30
THE MAHMAL.

The last ceremony in connection with the Mahmal will take place on Monday, the 31st inst., when all Government offices will be dosed. On the 3rd January, the escort of the Mahmal will leave Abbaesieh for Suez en route for the Hedjaz.
Ahmed Effeudi Arif has been attached to the Mahmal as physician.
KASR EL AINI.
Saud Pasha Zaghloul, Minister of Education, visited the Kasr el-Aini Medical School yesterday morning.

The commission of British physicians who are coming from England to examine the Kasr el-Aini students of the 1st and 2nd years are expected to arrive in Cairo tomorrow, 7. The examination will be held on the 23rd inst., and the results published on the 28th.
PORT SAID MOTOR CO.

To the order of the Port Said Motor Company, Messrs. Dougill and Co., Ld., of Leeds, have built a 22-seated motor char-a-banc, which was past through its trials in England recently preparatory to being employed on the Port Said to Cairo rode a distance of about ISO miles of level sandy country. The cars are of the friction driven type and are built to meet the requirements of the Port Said Company, who ask for cars of simple and reliable descrip- tion as mechanics are none too numerous in Egypt. The vehicle already tested is gear- less, and has an engine giving 20 h.p. at 800 revolutions per minute, accelerating to 30 h.p. at 1;200 revolutions. The flywheel is cast with a smooth surface, and the car is fitted with two direct-driven friction wheels running on a shaft. By shifting the disc of one of these two wheels across the face of the flywheel, the car can be moved in either direction, backward or forward. By these means also it is possible to obtain any gradation in speed, and the car when descending a hill can be pulled up with perfect ease by moving one of the leather-faced disc across the reverse side of the flywheel disc. To obviate any difficulty that might be experienced in running the car over the sandy tracts of Egypt the back wheels have been fitted with broad and flat twin tires. The run fully bore oat all that Messrs. Dougill claim for the car. A distance of thirty miles was covered at an average of sixteen or seventeen miles an hour, though the engines were not pat to a trial of their fall capacity through fear of the law.
NILE TOURISTS.

List of passengers by the P.S. Prince Abba*, which left Shallal yesterday Mr. Joaquin Crespo, Miss Carmela Crespo, Miss Delia Crespo, Dr. and Mrs. Leuobs Maok, Mr. and Mrs. C.C, MacMillan, Mr. and Mrs. H. Ball, Mr. and Mrs. F. Ball, Cav. G. B. Luciano.
